text: "aroma falls just a hair short of itc cousin Either, but the overall impact abd flavor are bettter. the cedar is not so strong in the finish, but evenly eveident throughout, and the complexity is the beers strongest point. licorice, honey, chocolate, roasted malt, hops, cigar...not as sweet as the other. VERY nice."

Dark beer with some cola highlights when held against the light. Short beige head. Big nose of alcohol, over ripe fruit and hop resin. Sweet beer with some burnt grain notes, fruit cake, molasses, and lots of pine and hop resin in the finish. Odd, style defying beer.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2016 Collaboration between three breweries, identical to their Either, but with other regional malts and hops. The result is visually the same, but aroma and taste clearly tend more to fruitiness, less dry, more honeyish and chocolatey and in all, rounder and friendlier; hops still govern the finish with a firm hand, strong and long-lasting. Fantastic brew, I liked this even more than the Either, already a very good and fascinating brew in itself.

Share from Boltz. Pours pitch black with a one finger tan head that leaves nice lacing. The nose is citrus hops, roasted malt and pine. The taste is roasted malt, chocolate, ripe citrus, coffee and a nice pine finish. Medium bodied. Nice black IPA. 3.7
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is a bit of pine, with chocolate and dark malt. Med body. Flavor is lightly minty chocolate with dark malt.
Bottle from Ibrew2or3. Pours black with not much head. Taste is chocolate black roasted malts with some evergreen mint. Or something
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours dark brown with a tiny beige head and a chocolate aroma. There is a rich chocolate flavor with a dry finish. A bit more subdued than the Either, but just as good.

Bottle shared at Ma Che in Rome. Pours black-brown with a foamy tan head. Burnt cedar wood on the nose with darkened grapes as well. Medium sweet flavor with lightly jammy dark fruits, light chocolate, grape jelly, mellow dry cedar wood. Medium bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. Light warmth to finish with a bit of bitter baking cocoa, earth, ripe and sweet berries. Lovely. Great depth of character.

12oz bottle thanks to Glouglouburp in an HF tulip. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malts (moreso than Either), some sweetness, a little chocolate and light coffee, some dough, and a little floral and lightly citrusy hops. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Smooth texture. A pretty good beer.

12oz bottle, thanks to FlandersNed. Sticker on cap reads "1-11". Shared with local raters. Very dark brown reddish, near black color. Thin khaki ring of head, couple dots of lace. Big body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Kind of chewy. Lightly dry finish. Smokey, roasty malt aroma. Some coffee and dark chocolate. Light molasses. Prominent earthy hop. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, light alcohol warmth works well for the 11.2% abv. Solid imperial black IPA, drinking well for 2 years old. Prefer this to the Either from what I remember, less oxidization and malty sweetness here.

Bottle. Thanks Tom! Pours pitch black with a very small foamy head that fades to a ring. Aroma is sweet chocolate, light pine, and burnt wood. Taste is sweet chocolate syrup and caramel up front, then turns to bitter coffee and burnt wood. Very light hint of hops. Medium to thick body, oily mouthfeel with a little chalkiness. Not sure how old this bottle is but its definitely lost some hoppiness. Wouldve loved to try this fresh. Everything but the hops have held up well though, very enjoyable.

Bottle, Theydon Bois Roma Pre-Nuptuals Tasting at Ma Che, 22/06/13. Thanks to Leighton for hunting down a 2nd Black IPA rate in Roma!
Dark black with a frothy tan head.
Nose is liqourice, aniseed, bitter roast, dark chocolate, hoppy backnotes.
Taste comprises dark malts, good dose of roast, light pine bite, touch of bitter hops, aniseed, licqourice, light chocolate.
Full bodied, soft carbonation, light booze in the finish.
Decent, more of a black IPA than Either in my book but both decent beers and well made with little thought given to the fact youre supping a double digit ABV beer!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.; thanks burg326).  Looks good; a dark brownish-black with beige lacing.  Smells solid; chocolate malt, hops, cedar, and honey.  Tastes like it smells with a nice, smooth mouthfeel.  Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours near black with almost no head. Aroma is roasted malt,licorice, grass, molasses, pine,citrus, wood, lime, bread, soy. Taste medium sweet, medium+ bitter and salty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is average. Finishes alcoholic and astringent.

Bottle. Dark brown with a minimal light brown head that leaves a bit of lacing. Aroma is chocolate, citrus, bready, honey, light coffee, roasted malt, bark, caramel. Taste is medium sweet and medium+ bitter. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Light roast and caramel with a light alcohol burn in the finish.

from Erzboerschof - black beer with no head retention; the nose is woody and piney; aroma of black chocolate and honey; pretty roasted; full-bodied and very tasty; some astringency, hugely bitter, pretty dry and long hoppy, chocolatey and woody finish - huge stuff !
pours dark black with a off white head. Aroma of bitter hops, alcohol and roasted malt. Taste follows, quite boozy, hops are there so i the roast but the booze takes over.  Either is much better
pours black with thin mocha head.  aroma of hops, woods, chocolate. Taste is chocolate, espresso, honey, cedar, hops bitter in finsh
Pours a dark black color with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, wood, and hops.  Oily finish with chocolate, roasted malt, honey flavor with a slight hop bite.  Great beer!
Tannin, deep raisin, bitter, mossy, bit of an edge, moist soil, burnt sugar, molasses. I really wanted a cigar with this.

Bottle shared at Delirium Hoppy Loft, side by side with Either.  Pours black with a medium thick tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, honey and roasted malt.  Flavour is heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter.  Thick oily mouthfeel, but not quite as thick as the Either.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.  An excellent beer in its own right, but slightly toned down compared to the Either.
Bottle at CCB Day, Sätila 2012-07-07. Black beer with a small brown head. Dried dark fruits, malty aroma and flavour. Nice beer :-)

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, july 19th 2012.
Black colored with a medium tanned head.
Roasty aroma with smoke, grapefruit, cocoa. Taste of roasted malt, grapefruit, peach, coffee. Good dry bitterness, and a lasting aftertaste of roast, cocoa and hops.

12 oz. bottle via normyk. Pours very dark brown to black with a small tan head. The nose has quite a bit of porter character with roasted malts, chocolate, raisin and other dark fruit, and adds the nice touch of cedar (mild) and more hops than Either.  The flavor has roasted malt, chocolate, raisin, cedar, dark fruit and more hops throughout. Mouth feel is medium to medium plus and there is less honey sweetness.  This is closer to a Black IPA than Either.  I enjoyed both for what they are and cant really favor one over the other.
Slightly better then either.  The taste is very similar but I thought this had slightly more blended flavors and was less muddled.  Roasty and citrusy with once again great drinkability.

Thanks to Palme ! 
Head: medium, espresso 
Colour: black 
Smell: chocolat, coffee, bit of anise, some fudge, hebral , ashy 
Taste: start is quite smokey, then ashy with a bit of anise. bit irony, some herbs, some alcohol, bit of coffee, actually more coffee bitter, end is grassy with again herbal notes and a slight touch of lime to my surprise ... nice one !

Bottle shared @ Timos/tkrjukoffs CCB Day tasting on July 7, 2012.Dark brown color, brown head. Grainy, malty, sweet scent. Sweet,a lcohol, malty taste. Grainy aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 355 bottle shared @ tkrjukoffs CCB Day tasting. Pours Hazy very dark brown, almost black, with a small brownish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sweet and hoppy with dark rye bread, lemon zest, black pepper, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, salty liquorice, bitter chocolate, coffee, alcohol, toffee, golden syrup, grass and hints of dry soil. Taste is sweet and bitter with roasted malts, liquorice fudge, sweetened coffee, dark rye bread, bitter chocolate, grapefruit juice, honey, orange zest, lemon zest, dry soil, alcohol, pine and hints of resinous wood and black pepper. Mouthfeel is harsh, oily bitter, tiny tart and medium to full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with burnt caramel, liquorice fudge, honey, grapefruit juice, grass, lemon zest, orange zest, coffee and pine.

35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 12.03.2010
Aroma is rather hoppy with exotic fruits, some roastiness and resin. Flavour is hoppy too with exotic fruits, some mango, resin, roastiness, coffee and licorice. Less roasted than Either and worse.

355 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a beige brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, raisins and hops. Flavour of roasted malts, raisins, toffee, very bitter hops, stinging wood, leather and dark chocolate. Some mellow honey-like sweetness as well. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, bitter and roasty finish with warming alcohol. A heavy Black IPA, smooth and very enjoyable.
bottle. pours light black with gorgeous white head. aroma of sweet hops. taste is slight roasty with lots of sweet honey

355ml bottle @ Craft Beer Co., London

Pours pitch black with a tiny light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, wood, fruits, honey and syrup. Lovely taste starts out slightly sweet and fruity but finishes roasty with wooden notes. Hints of bitterness, honey and smoke as well. Extremely well balanced and tasty.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Extremely dark and viscous pour with a brown head. Big nose of oak, roast, honey, and resin hop. Taste is similar, palate is full. Spectacular brew!

50 cl bottle.
Rated on 20110312.
Pours black color with small head. Aroma of hoppy fruits, caramel, malts and grass. Flavor of caramel malts, fruists and mild chocolate notes.
5425

12oz bottle.
Pours black, with an offwhite head.
Smells of malt, honey, and citrus hops. Flavors include soy, honey, coffee
Tastes excessively sweet, salty, and contains a medium bitterness -- an imperfect blend of the two that has my palate reeling, but ultimately is still pleasant.
Medium bodied, oily texture. Finishes somewhat dry, and peppery.

Bottled 355ml. Pitch black with a creamy deep beige head. Faint boletus in the nose. Niaouli, soy sauce, wood, caramel, strong coffee, alcohol and resinous hops throughout. Great balance. Smooth and complex. Full bodied. Strong bitterness. Impressive malt back. Peppery and warming on the swallow. The finish is very bitter, reminiscent of caramel, wood, nasturcium and citrusy hops. Interesting and quite delicious. I enjoyed this beer a little more than the either version perhaps.

From notes.  

lack with a tan edge and a decenty retaining tan creamy head.

More roasted malt, dark chocolate, and espresso than Either, with a little less milk creaminess in the nose.

The flavor starts with a light milk creaminess and sweetness, then it gets progressively darker and more bitter.  Roasted malt and chocolate wander in, with some a bit of pine in the back.  More malty than Either for sure.

The body is full, as is Either.  The high ABV also hides.

A little bit better than Either I think.

Pours black with a minimal tan head. Aroma in more of raisins than EITHER. Also has aromas of molasses, honey, and cedar. Taste is tobacco, thick roasted malt, and leather. In my opinion - not as good as EITHER.

My bottle [12oz] shared with garthicus & HogTownHarry -- c/o Glouglouburp. Dec. 13, 2011. Pours a very dark brown with a small frothy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, resiny hops, chocolate and dark fruit. Flavour of roasted malt, lots of resiny hops, some dark fruit,a touch of alcohol and a nice bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. I loved both this and the "Either", great stuff.

Black with a diminished head. Powerful coffee aroma with hints of cocoa, dark chocolate and roasted malts. The flavour is superb: dominated by sweet malts and a hint of citric bitterness. Its suprisingly balanced for such a heavy weighter.

Bottle. Looks the same as either. Black with small brown cap. Almost a purplish tinge. Aroma seems a little fruitier than Either. Rich fruits like Mamey, and its skins, drenched in rum. Not as oxidized or toasty in the aroma as Either, too. Tastes great, very smooth. Palate creamy. Leaves very long, lingering tasty espresso bean grinds on the tongue. Has almost a deMolen quality. The extra sweetness is a wonderful addition here, adding balance whereas either has more acidity. But there is balancing acidity here, in perfect proportion. Still a whole lotta roast, deep, and bittersweet cocoa. Strong but does not taste or smell hot at all. Smooth, balanced even though intense, and moreish. I believe I like this one a smidgen better than Either, overall.

Danish beer enthusiasts Aarhus south, dark IPA tasting: Is almost identical with Either model. Beautiful black colour with fine brown head. Roasted malty aroma. Very rich dark beer with an intense hop flavor. Not so alcohol strong in taste as the ether model..

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, shared with BBGTC. Oily black body, small off-white head. Aroma is licorice, piney tones of grass and dark malts. Hints of salmiac, milk chocolate and heather flowers. Wonderful. Taste is licorice, leather, cocoa, pine, grass and hints of dark chocolate and deep malts. Very nice. Mouthfeel is smooth and velvety. This one is almost up there with its "brother" Either, but lacks the little X-factor (the cedar, which is not as present?) to take it all the way to the Olympian heights. Close, though. :-)

12 fl. oz bottle, kindly shared by GrOve. Jet black. Low tanned head. Resinous and citrus fruity hop aroma. Tarry, wooden and heavily roasted malt aroma. Big malt body. Well roasted, lots of coffee/cocoa. Tones  of ash/smoke. Nice fruity hop flavor. Bold resiny bitterness. Thick in the mouth. Linger bitterness and well roasted malts in a lasting finish. Very tasty, very powerfull.

Black colour, brown mediumsized head that leaves some lace. Aroma is spices, some honeylike sweetness, mild liquorice as well as some slight berrylike notes. Flavour is rather similar with mild coffee and chocolate as well. Long honeyish sweet dark malty finish. This one was really pleasant.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Bottle opened at Mane Liquor. Big thanks to Jason for this. Poured viscous black with a very dense, semi-dark tan head. Head hung around for ages and left some nice spider legs down the glass. Nose is full of molasses and whiskey undertones at the forefront. As it warms, loads of mocha tones and piney hops come out with a touch of semi-sweet honey. The taste is liquorice and powdered cocoa to begin with. Nice, subtle touches of whiskey with a touch of warmth from the alcohol. Cocoa powder is very prominant and the hops linger for a fantastic amount of time. Heavy and almost milky in the mouth. Not much heat at all considering the abv, just a slight warmth at the back of the throat which is perfect. Fantastic beer and one of my favourite black ipas to date

Entering old rates. 12oz bottle. Couleur brune foncée, col beige. Quasi la même version que la Either. Lajout de malt pils donne un profile plus sec et amer qui ressort plus que dans lautre version. Le profile malté grillé reste bien présent avec un chocolat assez épais et un alcool réchauffant. Houblon est toujours bien en balance avec des notes fruitées ; agrumes et pamplemousse et peut être un peu plus sec. Encore une fois, le prix est me semble-t-il excessif. Reste une bière solide, mais qui est un peu trop alcoolisée. Les deux sont bonnes avec assez de différence pour en justifier de les gouter ensemble. Là aussi, le miel se fait discret et se perd un peu dans un océan dalcool et de houblon. Le cèdre confère toujours cette pointe dépice boisée assez agréable et qui se combine bien avec le houblon. Au final, cette version semble mettre les houblons plus à lhonneur.

Thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: Thick black body, thick brown head. Aroma: good spicy nose, blackcurrant, alcohol, malt, chocolate, mint and an almost cranberry. Flavour: Thick mouthfeel, malty, cranberry, mint, lots of chocolate and coffee. Lovely long malty chocolate
Finish. Lovely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle shared by blankboy with me and garthicus.  Fairly deep ruby with a large lasting tan/light brown frothy/creamy head.  Decent roasty and dry aroma, slightly lactic, dry floral bitterness, not much alcohol.  Taste - a bit more alcohol, raisin, slightly oaky, weak treacle, quite herbal, but low-level.  Slick, light mouthfeel, a bit astringent, modest carbonation, quickish slighlty boozy finish --- dry;  actually pretty solid.

12oz bottle. Black with a brown head that disappears very quickly, much thinner then its "either" cousin. Somewhat sweet malt, bit of smoke, pine resin and anise, bit of coffee and molasses as well. Fairly full bodied, moderately low carbonation, prickly from the booze, thick and somewhat tar like, sweet yet hot, even keeled throughout, stays very sweey, becomes dry with some smoke and pine at the end.

Pours black with a frothy tan head and solid lacing down the glass.  Aroma is pine, sweet malt, and a fragrant spice I cannot quite pin down.  Smooth feel in the mouth with pine, caramel, slight roast, a bit of wood character, and some lingering bitterness.  I preferred the overt cedar character of the "either" beer but this is still a very nice beer.

Bottle.
More piney than the Either, nice coffee bitterness. There is a pineapple sweetness creeping in here, too, which acutally works quite well.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of maximum12. Deep brown/black appearance with a sizable, dark brown head. Slightly charred, roasty dark malty, somewhat piney/citrusy hoppy aroma. Rich, very roasty, slightly smoky, slightly charred, dark malty, moderately piney, slightly resiny hoppy flavor. Good beer but not as good as some of its West Coast counterparts in my mind.

Small brown head. Opaque black body. Roasty herbal chocolate aroma with eucalyptus and pine needle notes. Dry-sweet roasty honey and coffee taste with pineapple and resin notes. Full-bodied. Dry-bitter coffee, cocoa, and tropical fruit aftertaste with earthy notes. Not really a great combination of flavours. (0.355l bottle shared by gr0ve.)

Bottle. Pours clear brown/black, thin tan head, soft lacing. Nose is sweet molasses, cocoa, soap, had this brew immediately on the heels of Either, and this one isnt faring nearly as well, seems lighter, thinner, and simpler, and perhaps most damningly: less hoppy. Flavours are at least somewhat hoppier, though the hops come off a bit soapy. Some light fruit, and moderate roast - Solid, but rather unexciting after the Either.

12 oz bottle care of DChmela. Thanks Bro. 
Wonderful black pour with a nice head. Crisp and bold. Spicy and full of flavor.

Deep rich black to brown coloured body with almost no head at all and slightly lighter in colour than the either. Aroma of pungent hops up front, alcohol, roasted malt, toffee, a touch of vanilla and a bit more hops on the back. Medium-bodied; Assertive roasted malt up first with a ton of hops hitting right behind and a good dose of sugars, followed up by a more hidden than either alcohol flavour, but its still a lot stronger than any other black ipa ive had. Aftertaste is potent with the roasted malt and the stronger hops bittering out the palate, left only in check by some light sugars and a touch of grassy herbal tastes. Overall, a nice beer - I preferred this one to the either and seems a bit lighter with a more pungent hop kick - however, they are both ridiculously strong and have a lot of character. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle in a horizontal taste with either, purchased from Knightly Spirits (Orange Blossom) in Orlando, Florida on 15-November-2010 sampled at home in Washington on 16-October-2011.

12 oz bottle.  Pitch black pour with decent head and some retention.  Nose of an IPA with a strong malt backbone.  Taste was hoppy and not as malty as the nose would suggest.  Lots of coffee.  Typical if many CC beers the mouth feel is fairly syrupy which works for Bug Sound but not so much for this offering.

Aroma: rich caramel and dark sugar, coffee, roast malts, cedar notes, moderate citrus, honey.  Pours pitch black, one finger of light brown head with reasonable retention, dissipates to a ring of foam over a few minutes.  Great balance of malt and hops; rich, chewy caramel, toffee, nice roasty and coffee flavors without being astringent, slight sweetness.  Moderately high bitterness and citrus hop flavors which pair nicely with the malt, honey, and cedar.  Full body, chewy, smooth, medium carbonation.  Great brew.
Black pour with aromas of coffee, roasted malt, citrus hops and honey.  Tastes of malt, honey, and pine.  Had a nice balance of hops and malt with a little bitterness at the end.

@ ACBF 2011. The aroma some citrus hops but far more coffee, roast and dark chocolate, some woody bourbon like tones. Black coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste has hopbitterness, charcoal, coffee and dark chocolates. Oily texture. Very full. Nice!

Initially Nose Is heavy bitterfresh hops and alcohol, then dark chocolate, heavy roasted malt, peppers, some oak, then, as is settles, decent bitter hops, feel is quite broad, carb is mediumlow, taste is heavy roasted sweetish malt, iron, leaves, cough syrup notes, decent hops bite

Sep 11. Black colour with a creamy brown head, smells sweet with a bit of roasted flavours. caramel or syrup. Taste has light sweetness to it but an complex mixture of malts and roasted wood. Very enjoyable..

Pour from a bottle shared from a kind person at Woodshop. Pitch black in color with a smidge of tan head. Nice toasty malt with caramel touches. Solid hop bitterness through out the beer. Finishes balanced with just the appropriate sweet malt flavors. Good beer.
Bottle, thanx to Nisse666. Pours black with a small, light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, hops, citrus and spices. Flavor of hops, pepper and dark malt. Pretty bitter finish, alcohol well hidden.

12 oz bottle, thanks Rauno! Black color. Sweet roasty aroma with coffee, licorice and honey. Roasty coffeish flavor with licorice, wood and tobacco. Bitter finish. Woody astringent mouthfeel, very woody.

355 ml bottle, from Ølbutikken (or possibly Høkeren), Copenhagen. ABV is 11.2%. Pitch black colour, moderate tan head. Compared to CC Either, the aroma is  very moderate: Dusty notes up front, followed by notes of mild coffee, hints of dark chocolate and wood. Warming mouthfeel. In the flavour, wood is up front, followed by malts, molasses, chocolate and honey. Distinct resinous hops in the finish. Good stuff, but Either is a tad better.

Bottle @ Home. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, coffee ande lots of citrussly / pliny hops. Taste is malt, coffee, sweet caramel, honey notes, grapefruit and pinelike hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, well balanced between the malty and hoppy elements with a lasting bitter finish. Very nice. 170811

Bottle. Pours pitch black, with a very small, creamy head. Lots of very pleasant aroma, with piny hops dominating and notes of tobacco, liquorice and coffee. Complex flavour following up the aromas, with a thick, oily body. Finish is long and very good coffee-ish bitterness.

Pours jet black with a minimal tan head.  Nose is coffee and malt.  I know this is "basically a black IPA," but it definitely smells like a stout.  The cedar is immediately apparent when you take your first taste.  There are some slightly bitter coffee and roasted malt flavors, but the honey really does a wonderful job of balancing them.  It is very apparent, in fact, that the sweetness comes from honey.  This drinks more like a slightly hoppy, slightly sweet stout than a black IPA, but I really like it.  Youd never guess this beer has such a high ABV.  Its really well crafted.
Black of color with a small brown head. An aroma of roasted malt, liqurice and bitter. A flavor of liqurice, roasted malt, bitter and oily.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a very dark brown/black with a red tint in the light. Small tan head. Aroma is sweet on the nose to begin with with lots of candied sugar, dark fruits, honey and caramel, then some coffee or espresso and booze. Flavour is wood, caramel/honey, candied sugar, espresso, with some liqueur style after burn/booze. Smooth, lightly carbonated, thick and warming. Good.

12 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany) split with Matts_Property, pours black with a slight reddish tinge and small ring of tan head. Aroma is balanced between roasted malts, honey and cedar, with the cedar becoming more pronounced the more you smell. Flavour is similarly so, with cedar, honey, slightly burnt roasted malts and wood all prevalent - the cedar and burnt / wood notes lingering. Again, not a huge fan of the cedar though its not as strong as in Either, and this is beautifully crafted nonetheless. More well-rounded than Either and I enjoyed it slightly more.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 33 cl bottle from Barley Wine, Copenhagen. Pitch black liquid with a reddish hue and small tan head. Aroma is roasty and hoppy with notes of grassy, citrusy hops, coffee, ash, black chocolate, wood, perfume. A bit vinous and some dark fruits. Taste is also very roasted with lots of hops, heavy bitterness and some sweetness. Medium bodied with ok carbonation. Overall, really good BIPA where the roasted and the hoppy notes work together better than usual.
Pours black with a creamy brown head. Nose is chocolate, citrus, pine and wood. Flavors are hops, honey, cocoa powder. Very tasty stuff!

0.33l bottle. Pours a quite black body with a medium sized chocolate head. Aroma is quite hopy. Much more so than the either. Also strong notes of mint, some chocolate and roasted malts with hints of chalk. Has a rich and almost chewy texture, soft carbonation and really full-bodied. Good roasted flavors, dark chocolate, some espresso-notes, dark fruits and it ends really roasted, rather woody, kinda sweet and really warming. Just gotta love it!

Pour is dark black, with a thin tan head, The nose is honey and cedar with notes of alcohol. The palate is....divine with bursts of hops, cocoa, honey, and cedar. Probably the best beer I have tasted in months.

Woow! On bottle. It is very similar to the Either! Black colour, malt and hop taste with a very flat froth. A "Chinotto Neri" taste in the finish is noticeable! Caramel and chocolate are noticeable too.

Bottle from Barley Wine shared in Sätila
AR: apricots, caramel
AP: dark, beige head
F: peppery, coffee, apricots, chocolate, caramel Either is the better of the 2 - more apricots in this one

Bottle 33 cl, courtesy of Nisse666. Pours pitch black with a creamy brown bubbly head leaving lace. Aroma is dry, malty, hoppy, cat bin, roasted and earthy. Flavor is sweet, pungeant, malty, honey and vanilla; more balanced than Either. Finishes peppery sweet and roastad malty.

Another find at Beer Heaven in Philly. Blacker than black pour supporting a tall dark khaki head with healthy curtains of lacing. Strong smokey aroma of roasted malt with a bit of earthy hops. Hops more forward in the taste with a good dose of pine, mocha, cinnamon, vanilla and semi-sweet chocolate. Stiff malt backbone. Silky texture and a long finish with a strong awarding alcohol punch at the end.
Bottle, thanks to Nisse666. Black beer, beige head. Hoppy earthy aroma, rather dry and a bit spicy. Hoppy earthy flavor with perfume and metal.

Bottle from whole foods Tampa.  Next to Neither.  In my new CCB snifter!  I liked Or better.  Thick Stout-y.  Citrus, pine, roast, residual sugars and wood.  Very nicely done.  Would love to try the DE & VT versions when the go down but prolly wont
Bottle next to either. Black pour with tan head. Pine, earthy and spiced aromas. Roasted, chocolate, pine, citrus and grassy flavors. Nice.

Bottle from Ølbutikken. Black with a brown, creamy film. Roasted, wooden, alcoholic bourbon nose. Sweet, wooden, bitter, liquorice mouth. Dry. Full body. Peppery finish. Sandalwood.  Alcoholic warmth.

Bottle at home bought at Vinmonopolet Vika
Dark dark brown, black in glass with a thin tanned head. Very nice lacings. Aroma has liquorice, coffee, citrus zests, grass and molasses. Full bodied some sweetness, roasted malts with tons of coffee and liquorice. Very nice. Feel is extremely oily, i like it. Somewhere around finish the citrus zests and grass rejoins and blasts into a nice bitter finish. Very complex hop aromas. This beer is awsome, i want more!
I also must say that Or is a much better beer than its sibling Either

36cl, Hill Farmstead/Grassroots version, brewed at CC, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, with honey, thx to Jeppe!, very complex bitter (more bitter than Either) brew, slightly roasted and fruity, yet not too heavy, balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!
Bottle at Joes, thanks for sharing. Another taste at Alvinne CBF 2011. Pitch black opaque color. Smell is ok, taste nice light bitter. Alcohol very well hidden, very nice body and carbo.

12 oz bottle from Five Points Bottle Shop. This stuff is absolutely delicious. The way Cigar City uses cedar is expert. Imagine a fantastic black IPA with good roast and hoppy citrus notes. Now add a touch of natural honey for a little balance to accompany the malts and cedar wood to mesh with the hops. The flavor is spectacular and the palate is spot on too: dense, slick and sensible for the character of the beer.  This is a winner.

Pours black with minimal head. 
What first hits you in the aroma is the alcohol. Yet there is more underneath, like dark fruits, wet wood, coffee and a little chocolate. There is also hops and malts evident aswell. Taste is filled with much of the same, only differences are more chocolate and more malty. It has medium long bitter aftertaste.

Pours pitch black with a medium mocha head...nice lacing and retention!  aroma has notable spanish cedar right away...also notes of cocoa and fig...slight sweetness from the honey.  Flavor is rich and complex with cocoa, honey, tobacco, and a nice dry woodiness from the cedar...perfect hoppiness to set it off...wow.  mouthfeel is thick and sticky with a long, very roasty finish.  Excellent.
Drank this one with joes, countbeer and benzai. We had both Either and Or and the Or was my favorite of the 2. Taste and mouthfeel were the best things about this beer.
Not much noticable difference to me between this and either. Well balance and again, hiding the alcohol pretty nicely. Notes, pretty big, sweet, hoppy, resinous. Raisins, wood and citrus hops. Nice.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted, smoked malt, coffee, alcohol, grapefruit. Flavour is roasted smoked malt, coffee, hop, grapefruit, alcohol. Full bodied nice beer.

12oz bottle from Capones, Norristown. Thanks, Matt! Pours very similarly to Either, near inky black with faint sediment, thick sticky head and a substantial look overall. The nose is very elegant for some so evidently strong and assertive: licorice, molasses, a similar bouquet of hops but with a bit more citrus tang, and more notable honey in the nose as well. The honey works spectacularly well with the cedar and dry-hopping, just a kiss of citrus too (less than promised in the nose). I think the use of the pils malts here really allows the various flavors to settle and blossom nicely, and this beer succeeds terrifically.

Thanks Smith4478! I meant to drink this closer to when I drank Either, but whatever. Pretty similar to Either. Seems like there is a tad more cedar. Every now and again I get fruity booze in the nose. Drink pretty good.

Bottle courtesy of Doodler poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of roastiness, cocoa, earthinesslight cedar, light honey and light dried fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roastiness, bitter chocolate, cedar and light honey with a smooth lingering roasty finish.

A: The beer pours a very dark brown color with a thin layer of off-white/tan foam.

S: Fairly heavy on the roast and chocolate notes with a moderate licorice quality.  Some mild booze is also in there.  A solid hop presence with a nice citrus (grapefruit) and pine note.

T: Grapefruit and other citrus hops are prominent up front.  A mild pineapple flavor as well as some grass and a hint of pine round out the hop profile.  Fairly roasty with a nice hint of licorice.

M: Medium to full in body with a medium level of carbonation.

O: I was expecting this to be pretty harsh at 11%, but really nice and easy to drink.

Bottle. An almost pitch black beer with an average sized, frothy, creamy, lacing, mostly lasting brown head. The aroma is modeartely malty, moderately to heavily hoppy, with notes of roasted grains, resin, pine needles, grapefruit, honey, hint of pepper and wood. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly sour, lightly to moderately bitter.  Medium to full body, oliy texture, lively carbonation, very long fiish with heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Like the either, almost burnt/charred malts in the flavor, but with more honey and perhaps even more hop presence. the cedar has a really good effect on this stuff. Apart the appearence I slightly prefer the Either version, but this is probably more true to this new Blac IPA style.
Black color/ tan head. Sweet floral, pine, honey, black malt aromas. Rich, smooth mouthfeel. Big pine sap, caramel, honey floral, dry black malt flavors mehing nicely--very good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle served in a tulip. Pours dark brown, burnt motor oil. Large milk chocolate colored head with decent retention and good lacing. Rich, sweet nose of cedar, molasses, honey, coffee, and dank earthy hops. Very sweet flavor. Big body, thick texture, soft carbonation, and an ultra long roasty, big bitter finish. Wow this is good!
Pours dark black with notes of a bitter citrus.  This gets into a sweet and sticky front palate that then shows burn orange peel and a dry lingering finish.
disclaimer-I DONT LIKE IPAs. hence the bad rating. im sure if i was a hophead, id love this. but its not my style. i mean, its amazingly complex and all. just in the end too hoppy for me.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty hoppy aroma with hints of licorice. Roasted malty hoppy bitter flavor with hints of licorice. Has a roasted malty hoppy bitter chocolate and licorice finish.
Or is a little more smooth and better hop profile incredibly smooth for an 11.2% beer. Lighty cedar flavor awesome brew

A black beer with a 1" head in a tulip./ The aroma is very hoppy, lots of citrus, orange, grapefruit, a little minty, and wood. The taste has chocolate, orange, lemon. The end seems to have a big bitter ending combined with some dryness from the cedar. This is a super smooth strong ale. The mouthfeel is thick and creamy and for whatever reason I enjoyed this better than Either but not by a wide margin.

[355ml bottle, courtesy of cgarvieuk] Looks the same as the Either  black and with a minimal head. Aroma more hoppy than the Either. Dry and bitter on the tast, although other than that the two are quite similar. Maybe more chocolate on this one. To be honest, this was my nineteenth beer of a tasting (Cigar City Either was my 18th), and by this point I was pretty mashed. All good fun though [08052011]
bottle at home ... dark black .... soft sweet roast ... little smoke hop ... soft rich fruity nose ... hoppier tha the either .. little more bitter ... little dryier ... bitter dark chocolate.

7 May 2011, bottle at one of cgarvieuks legendary tastings. dark brown/black, no bubbles. lots more coffee than the either. med body, slightly fizzy. more coffee and more bitter grass hoppy that the either.

Tap, Churchkey. Mahogany brown like the Either with an eggshell head. Lots of grapefruity hops in the aroma with a light sweetness, and much cleaner than Either. Roast, tobacco, light chocolate and earhty and grapefruit hops in the flavor.  Thicker and a little oily, but dry as well. Nice, and slightly better than Either for me.

Bottle at Churchkey, shared with some dude named Mike.  Slightly lighter, smaller head, variegated brown.  Aroma of burnt fireplace embers.  Taste has lots of dark roasted malts, slightly sweet, with a dry smoke and cedar chest finish.  Very nice.

Bottle; Pour is fairly dark black with a khaki head in this glass- So firstly ; a black ipa seems questionable to me as well, and not because of the ABV. I couldnt help but think ; heavily hopped cedar aged imperial stout, but what do I really know. What I can say for sure is that the OR is the better brew, having them (Either/OR) side by side. But only slightly. 

In this brew, you will find chocolate, honey, toasted cedar, licorice, with piney and floral hops present in better fashion than the OR ;to me this is the positive difference.

Bottle that was kindly passed on by Jan (Fonefan) many thanks Jan, shared with Peter Fowler, Shoulder of Mutton at tasting at his pub 28.04.11    Another very balck pour again its shark eye black with a beige head. Really roasty, but smoothness from the off robust in the mouth, liquorice again and there is dark chocolate. In fact along with woodiness (cedar?) noted a soft aroma of freshly laundered sheets, nice but unusual. This is just softer, touch hoppier and altogether more instantly likeable than the Either which may I add was very decent.   A7 A5 T8 P4 Ov15  3.9

12 oz bottle from Als beer store in Dupont Circle area DC.  Pours a nice deep black with light white foam.  Aromas are of leather, soy, anise, and wood.  Taste is sublime, an insane blend of bitter, sweet, dark, salty, and woody.   Wonderful beer.
Had this one at the ACBF 2011. Black colored brew. Malty, citrus and booze in the aroma. Flavor is ashy, bourbon, coal, roast, decent bitterness, some sweetness. Very enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle purchased at American Spirits in St. Pete, FL.  The aroma on this is much hoppier with piney notes, and light spicy hop notes when compared to "Either".  There is a light underlying roastiness.  This is pleasant and nicely aromatic.  Moderately transparent dark mahogany body with a smallish light tan head and good legging.  Starts really hoppy with significant piney notes.  Herbal, earthy hop flavors follow.  Good roast in the middle.  Finishes with more hoppy pine flavors.  A touch boozy.  This is definitely closer to a black IIPA than "Either".  Also more enjoyable.

Bottle 355ml @ Geokkjer
Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, alcohol and citrus. Taste is medium to heavy bitter and medium sweet. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

(Bottle) Pours black with a small and creamy brown head. The aroma holds more piny hops and honey compared to the Either version alongside new car, strawberry jam, bright but mild citrus, mild spicy wood, chocolate, asphalt and maybe some liquorice. Light fruity as well. The flavour is light to medium sweet, medium to heavily bitter and light acidic. Honey, roast, citrus and mild cedar. The mouthfeel is soft, velvety and light sticky with light to medium carbonation. Citrus, wood and cocoa on the finish. Near full-bodied.

Bottle courtesy of Meilby.Pours  black with a tan head.Aroma of peach, grapefruit, roasted malt and coffee.Flavor is sweet and warming with a nice bitterness and some roasted notes.Floral and peachy.Medium to full,average carbonation.Really nice.

Bottle, 12oz, thx to Meilby. A next to pitch black beer, topped by a dense, tan head of moderate size. The aroma is on the hoppy side, like sticking your head into a bag of American C-hops. Pine cones, resins and lots of citrus. Theres hints of roasted malts and a faint note of licorice too. The flavor is quite alcoholic, in a nice way, with roasted malts in the back and lots of hops up front. A good bitterness too. Full-bodied and warming, almost sticky. Lasting finish with alcohol, roasted malts and loads of hops. A big one, a wonderful one. 110420
Bottle thanks to Dmac.  Pours dark brown with a small lacing tan head. Aroma is of sweet malts, cedar and light citrus hops....similar to Either, but this one has a little more hop profile.

17-APR-2011, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Tasted side by side with "Either".
Pours very very dark brown with a huge brown head that lasts. Much more head than with "EITHER" and it really messes up the glass. Different pour hight or force? But it happens again with the second pour.
Roasted nose with spices, coffee and bitterness on the nose.
Taste is somewhat sweet with all the coffee and chocolate notes on top of a very present bitterness. Alcohol can be felt.
I am not really thinking black IPA here. More like barrel aged american strong ale as in "Lost Abbey" - like bordering on a stout. Best black IPA I have had. What a brew. Sadly it ends too quick. 99% alike but still... "EITHER" wins.

Thanks to Armin for bringing the bottle over!  Poured very deep black with a tight-bubbled beige head.  The aroma picked up a lot more hoppage than I got out of the "Either", with citrus and pine dominating.. the black malt base had a bit of licorice and nice roast, and complemented well.. the cedar and honey didnt play much of a factor there, but they werent needed.  The flavor was also led by the hops, and the cedar very much came into play.. drier, roasty black malts and a little sweeter honey at the core.. blended citrus bitterness and toasty cedar around.. warm, but not hot finish with a fine blend of the above.. very tasty stuff.  Medium-plus bodied and warm on the palate.. really dried out the mouth by the time it was all said and done.. I dont much like the style, but this worked well for me.

Pours dark brownish black, off white head. Aroma is pine and slight citrus, cedar, slight roast. Taste is citrus and resinous bitter, some sweet dark grout, finishing bitter and very dry, roasty. Good stuff.
(Bottle 16/3-2011) Better head then Either, and less sweet taste. A bit much ABV for the overall taste.
12 oz bottle from Capones. Just check my rating of Either and imagine the aroma is slightly less boozy and has a hint of citrus hops remaining.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Piney and resinous on the nose with hints of dark chocolate.  Pours black with a thin off white head.  Hoppy upfront with pine resin with a sweet molasses following.  Nice black ale.

Appearance: pours black with a nice espresso crema caramel head  tight and angel cakey. Bubbles along the edge. Swirls thick with a nice collar.

Nose: hops jump out first followed by twigs and woods, pine needles, and fir trees, tree bark. Nondescript dark fruits in the back along with dry tannins. Old leather, dark oiled and worn. Lovely. No evidence of the high ABV.

Palate: ooooh. Hoppy than dry and chocolaty, piney, barky, and dry. Fir trees, pine, bark. Dark bakers chocolate. Dark fruits underneath than dry tannins and nutty stones. Just like the nose, no real apparent ABV except for some warmth in the chest. Citrus pith  grapefruit. Of the earth.

Final Thoughts: not sure whether I liked Or or Either. Good stuff all around and I really enjoyed the addition of the hops. Very earthen, dense, and rich.

Bottle. Pours a cola black with no head. Aroma is a spicy hop with some peppery qualities. Taste is highly roasted malts with coffee and a slight chocolate. Subtle dark honey flavors compliments a very strong but well incorporated hop bitterness. Really a great beer from a great series.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ DOE Tasting, Fox & Hounds, Holstebro.Clear dark brown color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, mostly lastingg, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, honey, moderate hoppy, grapefruit, citrus. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, wood. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110329]

Bottle thanks to Kyle. Pours near black with a grayish brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has pine with roasted malt and a bit of dark chocolate. Flavor starts with roasted malt which is joined by pine and a bit of dark chocolate.

12 oz bottle from Beerlando. Poured into my CCB Tulip. Pours a dark ominous thicker black pour, opaque with moderate light brown frothy haed that cakes, stays decent sized, laces a-ok overall. Aromas are a bit more on for me than its counter part, piney and citrusy hops mix with roasty malts, smoothed out silky sweet chocolate, coffee, toffee. The hops seems more prominent on the nose, resinous hops, piney, take a touch of a dominant position. Initial is full bodied, offering a thicker malt bill, roasted malts and sweet toffee mix with touches of toast, toffee and a moderate blast of piney and citrusy hops, florals and a good bitterness with some touches of ABV related heat sticking to the throat. Touches of cedar spicy wood move into it as it warms, some more sweet malts, touches of dark fruit, molasses. Some cocoa, creaminess into the body with a sticky thickness that seems to envelope the palate pretty outright. These beers generally have a hefty malt bill, some ABV warmth and a solid hopping, but not enough for me for how big they are. Maybe theyve sat for a bit. This is better than Either by a measurable amount, but Ive had better Black IPA styled beers. CCB does wonders with their dark beers, but I guess Im in the minority thinking these are not world moving. A solid well hopped big black ale. Touch of smoky ashy earthy quality in the finish as it warmed more.
Bottle 355ml at home. Pours black with dense, tan head. Aroma is coffee, wood, roasted malts, spices, citrus. Taste is light sweet, medium bitter. Full body, oily, soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a large chocolate colored head. The aroma is malt, roasted, berries, wood and hops with citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a really good beer with a good balance and complexity.

4th March 2011Bottle at ACBF. Opaque black beer, small tan head. Fresh dark malt nose. Smooth semi dry palate. Fruit underneath with dark malt and some medicinal bitterness on top. Unusual and good. Lingering herby-bitter aftertaste.

12oz bottle courtesy of ibrew2or3. thanks, dave! pours a dark, cola-brown with a one-finger, khaki head and light, bubbly lace. aroma is great, very interesting, with heavy spruce, wet grass, grapefruit, and navel orange with subtle notes of roast, cocoa, and honeynut bread with just a hint of cedar. flavor is wonderful with the spicy cedar and spruce esters really shining behind the sweet honey, orange flesh, and light tropical fruits backed by roast coffee, chocolate, and toasted pecans. palate is full bodied and rich for an ipa with great carbonation and a pleasant warmth from the big abv. overall, a great black IPA.

Bottle. Courtesy of Hopscotch for providing this! It pours pitch black with a creamy light tan head. The aroma is liquorice, passion fruit, light peach, chocolate, hard roasted malt, grape fruit and spicy cedar. The cedar is quite profound in the flavour along with grape fruit, citrus, oranges, chocolate and hard roasted malt. A pleasant sweetness from the honey and malt balances the loads of hops used here. Very nice indeed!

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, alcohol, and wood. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, roasted malt, and soy sauce, leading to a very bitter finish. Thanks pinball for sharing.

pitch dark, small brown head.
roasted malts, winey note.wood. nice slighlty fruity aroma.
flavor is wood, roasted malts, loads of hops to balance. vineous touch.

Botle 33 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pours pitch black with a small beige head. Hard roast in the nose but the fresh citrusy hops dominate. Medium body, hard roast malt, some ashes and dusty hops. Heavy roast in the finish - AND bitter hops. 230311

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a coffee tan head with good retention.  Aromatically superior over the either.   Nice fresh cut grass tones, spruce, herbal and drying floral tones.  Lighter roast y bitterness, spicy ceder and drying herbal body.  The etoh presence is much less as well, or so it seems.  Nice offering would be better at a lower abv.

Bottle from Domus Birrae, Rome. Pours black with a creamy beige head.. Aroma of coffee, liquorice and some whiff of ginger.Taste is dry and bitter, liquorice in the front seat, also some wood and burnt dark malts. Very dry and bitter hoppy end.

Bottle.  Minimal tan head atop black body with brown edge.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, caramel, chocolate, some orange.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, bittersweet chocolate, plum/raisin, orange/grapefruit.  Sticky medium-full body, low carbonation, somewhat smooth.

Pours murky dark brown with a brown head. The aroma is fruity hops, citrus, a little pine, some cocoa, nuts, and hints of wood. The flavor is sweet up front with honey, earthy hops and some well balanced roasted malts. The finish feels more roasted than bitter even though the hops dominate the mid palate. The mouthfeel is very nice and rich, but not syrupy. Cedar notes come through as a hint of woody spiciness in the finish.
Bottle from Skjold Burne. Medium head with medium duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are coffee, chocolate, hops, flowers and licorice. Great beer.

Taster at DØE meeting, Aarhus Syd, DK. 
Bottled, 160311.
Black with beige head. Aroma of pepper and malt. Flavor roasted barley and wood. Thinner palate than Either.

Black with a light brown head. Aroma is raosted malt, coffee and hoppy - pine and grapefruit. Flavor is very sweet and very bitter. Finish is very bitter with warming alcohol. Not thick and creamy like Either, but still great. 160311
Bottle at ACBF 11.  Not as good as the Either.  Very deep brown colour, smoky aroma, bit medicinal.  Tasty dark roasted malts.  Coffee but medicinal throughout.

Bottle served next to its compatriot, via a trade. Pours with a brown head that is a bit thicker than the other version and lasts a bit longer. About the same color (a near black body). Aromas of baked bread, chocolate, flowers, vanilla and light coffee. Flavors are very bitter, lightly astringent (both versions were), light citrus, flowers, roast. Lingering bitterness. Decently hidden ABV. Medium to light bubbles. Decently well attenuated for the size of the beer.

Enjoyed this version a touch more than the "Either".

Beer B: bottle thanks to Drowland, sampled side by side blind(with Either), pours dark brown to black with a medium tan head that leaves spotty lacing down the glass.  Aroma is spruce tips, orange peel, booze, floral notes of honeysuckel, cocoa.  Flavor is bitter cocoa, thin coffee notes, less of a hop presence as its counterpart, but enough that its fairly balanced and the finish is dried out.  This one seemed a tad sweeter to me, but is still a nice beer.

Hoppy-roasty aroma.  Deep brown/black  in color with a tan head.  Really a stout-like IPA (the "either" seemed more like a IPA-like stout) with great coffee and chocolate flavors and a hop strength.  A great, complex beer.

Notes: Bottle at Alvinne CBF 11

Bottle @ Oddense tasting. Black body with a small brown head. Aroma is hops, citrus, caramel and smoke. Flavor is chocolate, hops, citrus, malt, light bitter coffee and wood. Bitter aftertaste. Nice lacings. Well balanced. This is the best of Either -Or.
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, heavy peach and citrus. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, light chocolate, heavy peach, grapefruit and citrus. High bitter.
[3/4/11] Bottle at ACBF 2011. Black. Aroma has some roastiness, coffee, some piney hops and some fruitiness. Burnt bitter flavor with quite a bit of of hops. Full-bodied.

Poured a very dark blackish brown with a good two fingers of head. The aroma is very heavy on the sweet malty and dark fruit. The taste is quite heavy molasses, maple syrup, but also an aftertaste of some significant piney hops. The body is surprisingly heavy on this one. A bit of alcoholic burn. A very interesting and well made dark ipa.

Bottle pours black with thick tan head.  Aroma is sweet hops, a touch of malt, and finishes with a semi sweet note most likely from the honey.  This beer has a lot more balance to it than either.  Its damn tasty.
Bottle. Black with small light brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, honey, perfume, bitter and hops.

Bottle, bought @ Skjold Burne, Aarhus.
All black with a large, creamy, light-brown head. Good duration and nice lacings. Aroma is lovely, good wood with piney and fruity hops. Mild vinious, some grapefruit, apricot, honey, plant sap. Medium carbonation, lovely light and creamy mouthfeel. Lovely balanced flavour, good liqourice, mild vinious, some coffee and bitter dark chocolate. Good hops bite, lots of pine, plant sap and grapefruit. Lovely beer.

Bottle at ACBF 2011. Dark brown coloured. LIght brown head. Herbs, caramel, light liqourice, roast, flowers, light spice and chocolate in the aroma. Flavou rof cocoa, coffee, caramel, vague smoke, some herbs and flowers. Very nice and smooth. Medium to full bodied. Has a hefty bitter roasted end. Very nice.

33 cL bottle at ACBF2011. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Spiced, dark roasted and dense malty aroma. Breadish. Smooth, sweet, roasted breadish and dark malty. Light hops fruity and rather bitter and dry roasted. Ends dry.

Bottle. Side by side comparison with "Or". Pours black with  tan head a little bigger than "Either" but faded just as fast. The aroma is more of what I was expecting from a black IPA compared to "Either". It has a lot more of the citrus, pine, hop notes on the nose as well as a bit of earthiness. The flavors are full of earthy wood notes, tobacco, and citrus. The bitterness was better fitting here than with "Either". The mouthfeel wasnt as full bodied and fit closer with the style. I preferred this over "Either"

Head gone in seconds over near-black beer with a beautiful granat sheen. C-hops, but with a very marked meaty ester presence, like the juices dribbling out of a fresh roast - with grapefruit. Again roasted in the mouth, with sweet, roasted, and just-not-salty flavours. Very rounded, filling, balanced. Alcoholwarming, very thick and near syrupy texture. This is both original and excellent - a rare combination to be cherished.
Very much the same as the "Either" version but more hops which goes better with the now lighter flowery taste.

Dark mahogany pour with a small latte head.  Aroma is wood, citrus, and caramel.  Flavor is sweeter and roastier than one would expect...kind of loses the IPA feel and seems more like a strong ale.  The 11.2% ABV is very well hidden.

(12oz bottle courtesy of drowland!).  Pours dark brown with khaki head. Aroma of wood, and some fruitiness.  Taste is bitter up front but has some chocolately notes to go with the smooth honey texture.  Medium texture with bitter, smooth texture.  Pretty nice for a black IPA.
Musta olut, vaalean ruskea vaahto. Pihkainen ja kahvinen tuoksu. Katkera ja kestävä maku. Hunajainen. Todella paksua. Jonkinmoinen pettymys hintaan ja odotuksiin nähden.
UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 Lots like the either version, but less Floral, more hoppy. Decent for sure.

Flaske: Denne øl løb lidt sammen med either. Sort gennemsigtig øl med et fint skumhoved. Duften er humlet men der kan bestemt anes honing i den. Smagen er igen humledomineret men med et tydeligt præg af honing uden det bliver for sødt. God øl.

After having the "Either" I can see why they named these what they did. I could drink either/or and be happy. Had the Either last week and I wish I wouldve tried them back to back so I could pick out the differences. Aroma was decent. Strong resiny hops. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a tan swirl on top for a head. Taste was strong and hoppy. Hot resiny and citrusy hops fill the mouth and dry the top. Just a hint of roastiness is evident..the hops and roastiness are not battling each other as is the case in too many of the style. The hops are strong and in the front while the roastiness just sticks around after the swallow. Perfectly done. A little hot from the strong alcohol. Good carbonation. Great beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Aroma of coffee (beans), hops (citra hops), citrus, honey and wood. Taste add some dark bitter chocolate, wood, spice and some alcohol. I hate to admit that I did not taste this together with EITHER but they seemed pretty simular although I think Either was a bit more aggresive.

Bottled. Pours opaque and almost black with a beige, medium sized, creamy head. Good lacings. Nose of roasted malts and dark fruits with grape and piny notes. Flavour with an appropriate sweetness, dark fruits, coffee and the hops are more subdued compared to "either". Full bodied. Flat carbonation. Oily texture. Ends up more dry with a nice, short bitterness. Close to an Imp. stout. Smoother than "Either" and very enjoyable.

12oz bottle my brother brought back from Tampa, thanks Jeff! Compared side-by-side with "Either." Pours a black body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, darker brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Actually a bit more on the creamier side and some more lacing than the "Either." Aroma is very similar to the "Either," but a bit sharper when it comes to the roasts and hops. Tons of toasted cedar up front with plenty of dusty and musty earthy hops. Plenty of caramel to balance, however, not quite as sweet and pronounced as the "Either." Lots of tobacco and some smoke, citrusy pines with light resins, roasts, dry cocoas, some pepper, and a touch of molasses sweetness behind the caramel as this warms more. Flavor has tons of sharper, heavier pines and earthy hops up front with lots of citruses. Lots of balanced, toasted cedar, roasts, tobacco, and a moderate char come in along with dry cocoas. This is slightly less sweet and juicy than the "Either," but I like how the bold, deeper flavors take the forefront in this one. The pines do grow a bit sweet towards the finish with a bit of a juicy citrus, but there is more of an earthy spice that adds more complexity to the hopping when compared to the "Either." Finishes very dry with plenty of resiny pines, earth, toasted and slightly charred cedar, heavy roasts, and tobacco smoke all balanced nicely by a solid caramel and cocoa. Very lengthy aftertaste following a medium, very soft and creamy, almost full body with a soft, creamy, medium carbonation. This is ever-so-slightly lighter than the "Either," but still drinks splendidly. Overall, this beer along with the "Either" are definitely my kinds of beers. Toooons of bold flavors all balanced extremely well with an exceptional palate. This one leans a bit more towards the roasts and deeper hop flavors, which I tend to like better. Very similar to the "Or," but I like this one a bit more because of the awesome balance and slightly deeper flavor. Damn, these two were spectacular.

Black. Has a light brown head, mostly lasting. Spicy, malty aroma. Citrus, pine, roasted too. Dry wood. Flavor starts dry, sweet, acidic, finish bitter. And then more wood, pine, ceder-wood, real nice. Long-long duration. Dry texture. Soft carbonation.
coffee, lakrids,black, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, nice beer.

Bottle Pours a pitch black color with a frothy tan head. Aroma is quite hoppy and fresh smelling. I get alot of graprefruit, citrus, some pine and roasted malt. A vigorous pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a four finger thick, nicely browned, dark tan colored head.  The beer is an approaching black, concentrated brown color that shows brown notes around the edges when held up directly to the light.  This is extremely hoppy and fresh smelling with notes of tangelo zest, lychee and lots of herbal notes that contribute notes of pine and even some nutty hemp seed aromatics.  There is a soft, supporting malt character here that provides notes of toasted / roasted malt and even hits of spicy grain (more crystal malt than rye).  This really is quite hop dominated though; the fruit-leaning hop character also contributes notes of ruby red grapefruit juice, concentrated floral tropical fruit notes.  At times the roast malt character is quite a bit noticeable (though still plays a secondary role), but at others it is quite consumed by the hop character.  As the beer warms up a spiciness and a touch of hot alcohol starts to come out a bit more, though the fruity hop character is certainly still the dominant note.

Lightly sweet tasting up front, but it is hoppy enough that it has a certain dryness to it.  As it rolls across the tongue an amped up fruit-hop character combines with the malt and accentuates a smooth sweetness; the combination provides flavors of lychee, orange blossom nectar, concentrated tangelo zest as well as kumquat zest flavors.  The finish has an herbaceous hop bitterness to it that is a bit green at times and gets accentuated by a roast / burnt roast malt character.  Despite how dark this beer is, the roast malt character is actually fairly subtle, really it is just that the hop character is quite aggressive and is most noticeable in the finish, though there is a touch of dark cocoa in the middle that subtly contributes to the flavor profile.  The body of this beer has some viscosity to it and some heft, though the hops help to balance this out quite well and make this quite quaffable.  There is a touch of heat that provides a warming to the finish of this beer.  Toasted, woody and earthy notes are found here in the finish and contribute a complexity here that is quite nice.

This is quite nice and tasty, once again though I am of the opinion that the dark / roast malt is just getting in the way in this beer.  It adds a harshness to the finish that accentuates a green, sharply herbal note towards the finish; traditional, pale malt IPAs provide a cleaner focus on the hop character that just works better.  Having said that, this is still a thoroughly dominated, hop focused beer that will satisfy the inner cravings of your inner hop-head.  I am almost done with this beer before I knew there was cedar used in this beer; it integrates quite well with the hop character and perhaps contributes an herbal, spicy and woody character that melds into similar hop notes.  Interestingly enough it also integrates quite well with the toasted / roasted malt character as well.  Actually in the end I would guess that the cedar character really helps to tie together the disparate roast character and aggressive hop notes quite a bit more than would otherwise be the case.

Common Rating for Either Black Ale  and Or Black Ale
In short: Big boozy roasted chocolaty beer with aggressive green and resinous bitterness.  Good sipper.
How: Bottles 12oz (Either + Or) side by side, fresh, about 1 month after the beers release
The look: Black body topped by a medium beige head leaving good lacings.  Either version has a slightly better head retention.
Mostly common between OR and EITHER versions: Uber-hoppy nose with a very fresh green hop peletts signature.  Taste has chocolate, medium roasted level, some dry wood.  There is a little toasted wood notes that dry out the beer a bit but I would not have guessed this was cedar barrels aged.  Very assertive bitterness that is both citrusy and resinous.  Appropriately smooth carbonation.  Tasty aggressive beer that are nonetheless pleasant to drink.
Differences between OR and EITHER versions: Either was more chocolaty and had a richer fuller body.  Or version had more honey sweetness.  Alcohol was a bit more apparent in Or version and was a bit bothersome. 
Bottom line: I found the Either (8-4-7-4-15=3.8) more interesting than the Or (8-3-7-3-14=3.5).  Im surprised by this result because I usually much prefer Hill Farmstead products over Cigar City.  The girlfriend and I drank both beers in presence of the Hill Farmstead assistant brewer.  He was very curious to know my opinion.  I told him the truth that I preferred the Cigar City version.  My mother always told me that it cost nothing to be honest.  And my father also told me that stealing peoples wallets not only costs nothing but can also generate a little profit.  Thanks dad!

The hop prove dominant over the underlying malt base of dark, bittersweet cocoa and dry caramel. Some chocolate roast comes through on the finish which blends well with the hop bitterness. Full bodied, smooth with balanced carbonation and a lengthy warming finish from the alcohol.
